title: Proverbs Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:1, who heareth his father's instruction?
questions.correctAnswer: A wise son
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:1 states that a wise son heareth his father's instruction.

questions.question: What shall the soul of the transgressors eat according to Proverbs 13:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Violence
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:2 says the soul of the transgressors shall eat violence.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:4, what happens to the soul of the diligent?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be made fat
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:4 contrasts the sluggard and the diligent, saying the soul of the diligent shall be made fat.

questions.question: Which type of man hateth lying, as stated in Proverbs 13:5?
questions.correctAnswer: A righteous man
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:5 clearly states that a righteous man hateth lying.

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 13:10, pride is the cause of contention.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:10 states that only by pride cometh contention.

questions.question: What happens to wealth gotten by vanity according to Proverbs 13:11?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be diminished
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:11 says wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:12, what effect does hope deferred have on the heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Maketh the heart sick
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:12 explains that hope deferred maketh the heart sick.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The law of the wise is a fountain of _______, to depart from the snares of death.'
questions.correctAnswer: life
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:14 says that the law of the wise is a fountain of life.

questions.question: Who shall be destroyed according to Proverbs 13:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Whoso despiseth the word
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:13 states that whoso despiseth the word shall be destroyed.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 13:16 says a fool deals with knowledge.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:16 states that every prudent man dealeth with knowledge, but a fool layeth open his folly.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:18, what is the result for him that refuseth instruction?
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty and shame
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:18 says poverty and shame shall be to him that refuseth instruction.

questions.question: Who shall be wise according to Proverbs 13:20?
options: He that walketh with wise men
questions.correctAnswer: He that walketh with wise men
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:20 states he that walketh with wise men shall be wise.

questions.question: What does a good man leave to his children's children according to Proverbs 13:22?
questions.correctAnswer: An inheritance
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:22 says a good man leaveth an inheritance to his children's children.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 13:24 says he that spareth his rod loveth his son.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:24 states he that spareth his rod hateth his son, but he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:25, what does the righteous eat to the satisfying of?
questions.correctAnswer: His soul
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:25 states the righteous eateth to the satisfying of his soul.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with impatience because their hopes seem delayed. Based on Proverbs 13, what biblical truth would you share about hope and patience?
options: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but when the desire comes, it is a tree of life.
Hope always brings immediate joy and fulfillment.
Delaying hope is a sign of lack of faith.
One should abandon hope if it is delayed too long.
questions.correctAnswer: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but when the desire comes, it is a tree of life.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:12 teaches that although waiting can be painful, the fulfillment of desire brings life and joy. This encourages patience and trust in God's timing. Supporting verses include Proverbs 13:12, Proverbs 13:20 (walking with the wise), and Proverbs 13:14 (the law of the wise as life).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13 instruct us regarding the value of diligent work versus laziness?
options: The soul of the diligent shall be made fat, but the sluggard desires and has nothing.
Diligence is unnecessary if God provides.
Sluggards will be rewarded for their patience.
questions.correctAnswer: The soul of the diligent shall be made fat, but the sluggard desires and has nothing.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:4 contrasts the diligent who prosper with the lazy who remain empty-handed, highlighting the biblical value of hard work and discipline. Related verses include Proverbs 13:11 (wealth gotten by labor increases) and Proverbs 13:23 (food from tillage).

questions.question: What warning does Proverbs 13 give about the use of our words and speech?
options: He that keeps his mouth keeps his life, but he who opens wide his lips shall have destruction.
Speaking much is always wise and helpful.
Silence is a sign of weakness.
One should always speak without restraint.
questions.correctAnswer: He that keeps his mouth keeps his life, but he who opens wide his lips shall have destruction.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:3 teaches the importance of self-control in speech, showing that reckless words can lead to harm, while restraint preserves life. Supporting verses include Proverbs 13:2 (fruit of the mouth) and Proverbs 13:16 (prudence in dealing with knowledge).

questions.question: A parent wants to discipline their child lovingly. Based on Proverbs 13, what is the biblical principle for parental discipline?
options: He that spares the rod hates his son, but he that loves him chastens him early.
Discipline should be avoided to maintain peace.
Love means never correcting a child.
Only punish children when they are adults.
questions.correctAnswer: He that spares the rod hates his son, but he that loves him chastens him early.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:24 teaches that loving discipline is necessary for a child's growth and protection. This principle is supported by Proverbs 13:18 (regards instruction) and Proverbs 13:1 (wise son heareth instruction).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13 describe the character of a righteous person compared to a wicked person?
options: A righteous man hates lying; a wicked man is loathsome and comes to shame.
The wicked are always honored, but the righteous face shame.
questions.correctAnswer: A righteous man hates lying; a wicked man is loathsome and comes to shame.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:5 contrasts the integrity of the righteous who reject falsehood with the disgrace that follows wickedness. This aligns with Proverbs 13:6 (righteousness keeps upright) and Proverbs 13:9 (light of the righteous rejoices).

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 13, pride is the root cause of contention.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:10 explicitly states that pride brings contention, while wisdom comes with good counsel. This highlights humility as key to peace, supported by Proverbs 13:16 (prudent with knowledge) and Proverbs 13:20 (walking with wise men).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13 teach about the relationship between wealth and integrity?
options: Wealth gained by vanity will diminish, but he that gathers by labor will increase.
All wealth is guaranteed by God regardless of how it is obtained.
Riches make a man wise automatically.
Pursuing wealth is more important than honesty.
questions.correctAnswer: Wealth gained by vanity will diminish, but he that gathers by labor will increase.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:11 emphasizes the value of honest labor over vain or ill-gotten gains. It is complemented by Proverbs 13:7 (appearance of riches vs reality) and Proverbs 13:22 (inheritance for descendants).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The law of the wise is a fountain of ____, to depart from the snares of death.'
questions.correctAnswer: life
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:14 states that the law of the wise provides life and protection from death’s traps, illustrating the life-giving power of godly wisdom and obedience.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13 counsel us to choose our companions for spiritual growth?
options: He that walks with wise men shall be wise, but a companion of fools shall be destroyed.
Companions do not affect one's wisdom or character.
questions.correctAnswer: He that walks with wise men shall be wise, but a companion of fools shall be destroyed.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:20 teaches the importance of surrounding ourselves with wise people for mutual growth and warns of the destructive influence of foolish companions. This is supported by Proverbs 13:16 (prudence) and Proverbs 13:10 (pride and contention).

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 13, a poor person is more likely to accept rebuke than a rich person.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:8 states that the poor do not hear rebuke, while the ransom of a man's life are his riches, implying the rich may resist correction. This is linked to Proverbs 13:18 (refusing instruction leads to shame) and Proverbs 13:1 (wise son hears instruction).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13 say about the consequences of despising God's word?
options: Whoso despiseth the word shall be destroyed, but he that feareth the commandment shall be rewarded.
Despising the word has no consequences.
Only the foolish benefit from God's word.
The word is optional for believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Whoso despiseth the word shall be destroyed, but he that feareth the commandment shall be rewarded.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:13 warns that rejecting God's word leads to destruction, while reverence for His commands brings reward. This is supported by Proverbs 13:14 (law of the wise) and Proverbs 13:15 (good understanding gives favor).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13 describe the reward for those who regard reproof and instruction?
options: Poverty and shame shall be to him that refuseth instruction, but he that regardeth reproof shall be honoured.
Reproof should always be ignored to avoid shame.
Instruction leads to immediate riches regardless of obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty and shame shall be to him that refuseth instruction, but he that regardeth reproof shall be honoured.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:18 teaches that accepting correction leads to honor, while rejecting it results in poverty and shame. This reinforces the biblical principle of humility and growth through correction, also supported by Proverbs 13:1 and Proverbs 13:24.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13, what characterizes a faithful messenger compared to a wicked one?
options: A wicked messenger falls into mischief, but a faithful ambassador brings health.
A faithful messenger is often despised and rejected.
Wicked messengers are rewarded by God.
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked messenger falls into mischief, but a faithful ambassador brings health.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:17 highlights the importance of integrity and faithfulness in communication and service, contrasting the harm caused by wicked messengers with the blessing of faithful ones. Related verses include Proverbs 13:3 (guarding the mouth) and Proverbs 13:16 (prudence).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13 describe the inheritance left by a good man?
options: A good man leaves an inheritance to his children's children, but the sinner’s wealth is stored for the righteous.
A good man hoards wealth for himself only.
Inheritance is meaningless according to Proverbs.
The wealth of sinners will last forever.
questions.correctAnswer: A good man leaves an inheritance to his children's children, but the sinner’s wealth is stored for the righteous.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:22 teaches the blessing of generational stewardship and God's justice in rewarding the righteous with what the wicked lose. This reflects biblical values of generosity and trust in God's provision, supported by Proverbs 13:11 (increase through labor).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to lie to avoid shame. What biblical principle from Proverbs 13 would you share?
options: A righteous man hates lying, but a wicked man is loathsome and comes to shame.
It is acceptable to lie if it benefits you.
Lying is a sign of wisdom and cunning.
Shame should be avoided at all costs, even if it means lying.
questions.correctAnswer: A righteous man hates lying, but a wicked man is loathsome and comes to shame.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:5 teaches that integrity is crucial and lying leads to disgrace. This encourages believers to trust God rather than compromising truth, also supported by Proverbs 13:6 (righteousness keeps upright) and Proverbs 13:25 (righteous eat to satisfaction).

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 13.

questions.question: In Proverbs 13:1, how is a wise son described in relation to his father's instruction, and what does this reveal about the value of parental wisdom in ancient Israelite culture?
options: He hears and values his father's instruction
He is indifferent to his father's instruction
questions.correctAnswer: He hears and values his father's instruction
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:1 states, 'A wise son heareth his father's instruction,' emphasizing the importance of honoring and learning from parental guidance, a key virtue in ancient Israelite society.

questions.question: Proverbs 13:3 contrasts the outcomes of controlling one's speech versus speaking carelessly. What is the promised outcome for the one who keeps his mouth?
questions.correctAnswer: He keeps his life
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'He that keepeth his mouth keepeth his life,' suggesting that restraint in speech preserves one's well-being, reflecting a Hebrew wisdom principle valuing self-control.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:4, what is the contrast between the soul of the sluggard and the soul of the diligent, and how does this reflect the cultural ethic of labor?
options: The sluggard desires but has nothing, the diligent shall be made fat
Both the sluggard and the diligent prosper equally
The sluggard works hard, the diligent rests
The diligent desires but has nothing, the sluggard is satisfied
questions.correctAnswer: The sluggard desires but has nothing, the diligent shall be made fat
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:4 highlights the reward of diligence against the futility of laziness, a reflection of the strong cultural emphasis on hard work for survival in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Proverbs 13:5 where the righteous and the wicked are contrasted, and how does this device function in Hebrew poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithetical parallelism
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:5 contrasts 'A righteous man hateth lying' and 'a wicked man is loathsome,' an example of antithetical parallelism common in Hebrew poetry to emphasize moral opposites.

questions.question: In Proverbs 13:7, what paradox is presented regarding wealth and poverty, and what might this imply about appearances versus reality?
options: One makes himself rich yet has nothing; one makes himself poor yet has great riches
Poverty is always due to lack of effort
Wealth and poverty are determined by divine fate
questions.correctAnswer: One makes himself rich yet has nothing; one makes himself poor yet has great riches
questions.explanation: This verse uses paradox to question superficial judgments, suggesting that true wealth is not always material and that external appearances can be deceptive.

questions.question: Proverbs 13:10 states, 'Only by pride cometh contention: but with the well advised is wisdom.' How does this link the theme of pride to social discord, and what does it reveal about the ancient view of wisdom?
options: Pride leads to contention, wisdom comes from counsel
Pride leads to peace, wisdom comes from solitude
Pride leads to silence, wisdom comes from debate
Pride leads to prosperity, wisdom comes from wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to contention, wisdom comes from counsel
questions.explanation: The verse connects pride with conflict and contrasts it with the wisdom that arises from seeking advice, reflecting a communal ethic valuing humility and counsel.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13:11 address the sustainability of wealth, and which New Testament verse echoes a similar teaching on the nature of wealth acquisition?
options: Wealth gained by vanity will diminish; labor leads to increase
questions.correctAnswer: Wealth gained by vanity will diminish; labor leads to increase
questions.explanation: This verse warns against ill-gotten gains, paralleling 1 Timothy 6:10 which cautions against the love of money. Both promote honest labor for lasting prosperity.

questions.question: Proverbs 13:12 uses the metaphor 'Hope deferred maketh the heart sick: but when the desire cometh, it is a tree of life.' What is the significance of the 'tree of life' imagery in this context?
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes vitality and fulfillment
questions.explanation: The 'tree of life' metaphor evokes imagery from Genesis and Revelation, symbolizing abundant life and joy when desires are fulfilled, contrasting with the despair of delayed hope.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 13:14 suggests that the law of the wise provides a source of life and protection from death's snares.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'The law of the wise is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death,' affirming the protective and life-giving nature of wisdom's law.

questions.question: In Proverbs 13:16, how is prudence contrasted with folly, and what does this reveal about the value placed on knowledge in Hebrew wisdom literature?
options: Prudent men act with knowledge; fools expose their folly
Fools are more knowledgeable than prudent men
questions.correctAnswer: Prudent men act with knowledge; fools expose their folly
questions.explanation: This verse highlights that prudence involves thoughtful action based on knowledge, while folly is characterized by reckless openness, underscoring knowledge's central role in wisdom.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:17 indicate about the roles and consequences associated with messengers, and how does this reflect ancient Near Eastern communication practices?
options: A wicked messenger falls into mischief; a faithful ambassador brings health
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked messenger falls into mischief; a faithful ambassador brings health
questions.explanation: The verse underscores the importance of integrity in messengers, reflecting the critical role of trustworthy communication in ancient diplomatic and social relations.

questions.question: Proverbs 13:20 contrasts the outcomes of associating with the wise versus fools. What is the promised outcome for the companion of fools?
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be destroyed
questions.explanation: The verse warns that companionship influences one's fate, with fools leading to ruin, reinforcing the communal responsibility emphasized in Hebrew ethics.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13:24's command about sparing the rod reflect ancient Israelite child-rearing practices and theological views on discipline?
options: He that spareth his rod hateth his son; he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes
Parents were encouraged to be lenient
Love was shown by sparing discipline
questions.correctAnswer: He that spareth his rod hateth his son; he that loveth him chasteneth him betimes
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the cultural norm that loving discipline was essential for proper upbringing, linking physical correction to care and moral formation.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:25 say about the satisfaction of the righteous compared to the wicked, and how does this relate to broader biblical themes of provision and justice?
options: The righteous eat to satisfy their soul; the wicked's belly shall want
Both the righteous and wicked are satisfied
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous eat to satisfy their soul; the wicked's belly shall want
questions.explanation: This verse contrasts the spiritual and physical fulfillment of the righteous with the deprivation of the wicked, echoing themes of divine justice and blessing.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:18, what are the consequences of refusing instruction, and how does this reflect the prophetic tradition's emphasis on correction?
options: Poverty and shame come to him who refuses instruction
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty and shame come to him who refuses instruction
questions.explanation: The verse aligns with prophetic calls for repentance, showing that rejecting correction leads to social and spiritual downfall.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:1, how does a wise son respond to his father's instruction?
questions.correctAnswer: He heareth his father's instruction
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:1 states that a wise son listens to his father's instruction, indicating humility and teachability. This aligns with biblical teachings on wisdom as humility and respect for parental guidance (Ephesians 6:1-3, Colossians 3:20, Proverbs 1:8, Psalm 111:10, Hebrews 12:9).

questions.question: What is the consequence of keeping one's mouth as described in Proverbs 13:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping his life
questions.explanation: Proverbs 13:3 teaches that guarding one's speech preserves life, reflecting the biblical principle that words have power to build or destroy (James 3:5-10, Ephesians 4:29, Matthew 12:36-37, Psalm 34:13, Proverbs 21:23).

questions.question: In Proverbs 13:4, what characterizes the soul of the diligent compared to the sluggard?
options: The diligent soul shall be made fat
The diligent soul desires but has nothing
questions.correctAnswer: The diligent soul shall be made fat
questions.explanation: The diligent are rewarded with abundance, while the sluggard's desires remain unfulfilled (Proverbs 10:4, Proverbs 12:24, 2 Thessalonians 3:10, Colossians 3:23, Hebrews 6:12). This reflects God's blessing on faithful labor.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:5 say about the behavior of a righteous man versus a wicked man?
options: The righteous man hates lying; the wicked man is loathsome and ashamed
The wicked man is praised for honesty
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous man hates lying; the wicked man is loathsome and ashamed
questions.explanation: This verse contrasts the righteous, who abhor falsehood, with the wicked, who are detestable and experience shame. This reflects God's holiness and hatred of sin (Psalm 34:13, Proverbs 12:22, Ephesians 4:25, Colossians 3:9, Revelation 21:8).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:7, what paradox exists regarding wealth and possessions?
options: Some make themselves rich yet have nothing; others make themselves poor yet have great riches
All who are rich have great possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Some make themselves rich yet have nothing; others make themselves poor yet have great riches
questions.explanation: This illustrates the biblical truth that true wealth is not always material (1 Timothy 6:6-10, Luke 12:15, Matthew 6:19-21, James 2:5, Ecclesiastes 5:10). Spiritual riches often surpass earthly wealth.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:10 identify as the root cause of contention?
questions.correctAnswer: Pride
questions.explanation: Pride leads to conflict, whereas wisdom brings peace and understanding (James 4:6, Proverbs 16:18, Philippians 2:3, Romans 12:16, Galatians 5:26). This theme is consistent throughout Scripture emphasizing humility.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13:11 describe wealth obtained by vain means?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be diminished
questions.explanation: Wealth gained quickly or dishonestly is unstable and ephemeral, while diligence leads to increase (Proverbs 21:5, Ecclesiastes 5:10, 1 Timothy 6:9-10, Matthew 6:19-20, Luke 16:10).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:14 say about the law of the wise?
options: It is a fountain of life to depart from the snares of death
questions.correctAnswer: It is a fountain of life to depart from the snares of death
questions.explanation: The wise law provides life and protection from spiritual death, prefiguring Christ as the source of life and the fulfillment of the law (Psalm 119:93, John 10:10, Romans 7:12, James 1:25, Matthew 4:4).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:16, how does a prudent man differ from a fool?
options: A prudent man deals with knowledge; a fool reveals his folly
A prudent man is silent; a fool is wise
questions.correctAnswer: A prudent man deals with knowledge; a fool reveals his folly
questions.explanation: Prudence involves thoughtful, knowledgeable action, while folly is exposed through rash behavior (Ecclesiastes 10:12, Proverbs 14:8, James 1:5, Proverbs 17:28, Proverbs 26:11).

questions.question: What outcome does Proverbs 13:17 associate with a wicked messenger versus a faithful ambassador?
options: A wicked messenger falls into mischief; a faithful ambassador brings health
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked messenger falls into mischief; a faithful ambassador brings health
questions.explanation: This verse illustrates the importance of integrity in communication, reflecting God's truthfulness and the health that comes from faithful witnesses (2 Corinthians 5:20, Proverbs 11:13, John 8:32, Ephesians 4:25, Colossians 3:9).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:18 warn about refusing instruction?
options: Poverty and shame shall be to him
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty and shame shall be to him
questions.explanation: Rejecting correction leads to downfall and disgrace, consistent with biblical teaching on the necessity of discipline (Hebrews 12:5-11, Proverbs 10:17, Proverbs 15:32, Psalm 94:12, Revelation 3:19).

questions.question: What is promised to one who fears the commandment according to Proverbs 13:13?
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be rewarded
questions.explanation: Reverence for God's commands results in blessing, aligning with the principle of obedience leading to life (Deuteronomy 28:1-2, Psalm 112:1, John 14:15, Romans 6:17, James 1:25).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 13:20 describe the outcome of walking with wise men versus companions of fools?
options: One becomes wise; the other is destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: One becomes wise; the other is destroyed
questions.explanation: This highlights the biblical principle of the influence of one's associations (1 Corinthians 15:33, Psalm 1:1-3, Proverbs 27:17, Ecclesiastes 4:9-10, 2 Corinthians 6:14).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 13:22, what does a good man leave to his descendants?
options: An inheritance to his children's children
questions.correctAnswer: An inheritance to his children's children
questions.explanation: The good man plans for future generations, reflecting God's covenant blessings and care for lineage (Psalm 112:6-9, Genesis 17:7, Proverbs 19:14, 2 Corinthians 12:14, Deuteronomy 6:6-7).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 13:24 say about sparing the rod in the context of discipline?
options: He that spareth his rod hateth his son
He that spares the rod loves his son
questions.correctAnswer: He that spareth his rod hateth his son
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes the necessity of timely discipline as an expression of love, consistent with biblical teaching on correction (Hebrews 12:6-11, Proverbs 3:11-12, Revelation 3:19, Ephesians 6:4, Proverbs 19:18).
